Here is what's at risk with taxes on us Investors in November's election:Kamala Harris and Biden together stated last winter that they would liketo tax long-term capital gains as "ordinary income". So, a TOST investorin a 24% tax bracket selling his stock would be taxed $2,400 instead of$1,500 for his $10,000 capital gain.But Harris/Biden also don't like Trump's 2017 tax cuts, so letting themexpire next year would turn a 24% marginal tax bracket into a 28% taxbracket and the stock sale would be taxed $2,800. That would almostDOUBLE it! Mr. Trump likes the LT gain tax right where it is at 15%.Harris/Biden have also stated that the top corporate tax rate (the one thataffects TOST the most) should be increased from 21% currently to 28%, anincrease of 33% on this company that would certainly hurt it's performanceand stock price.Mr. Trump wants to reduce the corporate rate from 21% to 15%. Like the LTgain tax proposals, Harris wants the rate almost DOUBLE what Mr. Trumpwants it to be.Harris also wants to tax un-realized gains for higher income investors. All othertax increases listed above impact ALL investors.Kamala Harris has always been anti-business/anti-investor. Her presidencywould be bad for the market and bad for TOST. It's not investors like us whowould be electing her. It's people like Taylor Swift fans who have no ideawhat Harris has in mind to do to us.And it's not like Harris wants people to know. She absolutely refuses to doa news conference.

I own a bit of TOST but I'm reluctant to get too aggressive with it. When, I look at reviews (understanding upset clients are more likely to review than happy clients), one theme that recurs is that it used to be better than it is now.  I see a lot of comments which state something like "I used to like it but it's getting harder to use, the support stinks, and they are now nickel and diming me to death" .  Are they expanding the business more quickly than they can support?

I've been in the payments space for 30+ years and I really like the Toast platform and business model.  To be clear, I've never worked directly with Toast.  That said, does anyone who has dug into TOST financials have thoughts as to why the stock price has been so anemic?  Every quarter they seem to meet/beat expectations and they are growing and the platform itself is really good -- so why does it seem to vacillate between $21-25?  Is the $13B market cap too rich?  Are folks waiting until it becomes profitable?  Not enough Wall Street coverage?  I bought a few shares but would love to go "all in" on Toast!  What am I missing?  Thanks and good luck, Longs!
Implementing this platform is like checking into the hotel California, people never leave.

I retired 10 years ago to travel. When that became exhausting we decided to spend our time in a different town each season. Since we were going to be in Colorado all summer last year I decided to take a job pouring beer at a popular pizza shop. I worked Friday and Saturday nights and had some fun, but the best thing I took away from the experience was this incredible Tost platform. I‚Äôve been trading it fearlessly because I saw firsthand what an incredible product it is. The end users love it. The owner of the shop complained about all the fees, but acknowledged he couldn‚Äôt get out of this solution into something else without significant interruption and cost. I implemented oracle financial software back in the 90s. This is the oracle of restaurant management. Go look at oracle stock and how it has performed since the 90s. I don‚Äôt need any money, but this stock is going to make my beneficiaries very wealthy.

Today is nothing more than market action. After the last couple of days of market "turmoil" margins calls are being enforced. On higher volatility stocks it is normal for margin requirements to increase in the face of perceived increased risk. Years ago I was a compliance officer....nothing in the conference call indicated a deterioration of outlook or the business. Growth remains on track. Markets breathe, and so should we. Nothing about this week causes me any concern. This is a solid company with a solid business model, generating sufficient free cash flow and growing rapidly. Nothing here to worry about.

I thought the Q2 results  were pretty good.  However there is  one thing which concerns me.    Despite spending  over $30MM on  stock  buybacks the number of fully  diluted shares outstanding rose ~11% year over year and ~5% for the  first half.  You can get to an "adjusted" figure which looks good by eliminating the reported cost of stock issued for compensation, but those shares remain  outstanding forever and are  forever dilutive.  This is a cost of growth.

ARR as of June 30, 2024 was $1.5 billion, up 29% year over year. ‚Ä¢ Gross Payment Volume (GPV) increased 26% year over year to $40.5 billion. ‚Ä¢ Total Locations increased 29% year over year to approximately 120,000. ‚Ä¢ GAAP subscription services and financial technology solutions gross profit was up 27% year over year from Q2 2023 to $330 million. Non-GAAP subscription services and financial technology solutions gross profit grew 29% year over year to $344 million. ‚Ä¢ GAAP operating income was $5 million in Q2 2024 compared to GAAP operating loss of $(80) million in Q2 2023. ‚Ä¢ GAAP net income was $14 million in Q2 2024 compared to net loss of $(98) million in Q2 2023. Adjusted EBITDA was $92 million in Q2 2024 compared to Adjusted EBITDA of $15 million in Q2 2023. ‚Ä¢ Net cash provided by operating activities of $124 million and Free Cash Flow of $108 million in Q2 2024, compared to net cash provided by operating activities of $50 million and Free Cash Flow of $39 million, respectively, in Q2 2023.

Added approximately 8,000 net new Locations in second quarter 2024 Annualized recurring run-rate (ARR) as of June 30, 2024 grew 29% to $1.5 billion Achieved GAAP operating income of $5 million in second quarter Net income was $14 million and Adjusted EBITDA was $92 million in second quarter
